text: Hello.
My name is Jimin Nam.

And I'm a fourth year
PhD student here at HBS.

And today I'm
going to be talking

to you about differentiating
on diversity.

And it's a joint project with
Maya Balakrishnan and Ryan
Buell.

I want to start off by talking
about the Equal Employment

Opportunity reports
or the EEO-1 reports.

These were embedded in the
Civil Rights Act back in 1964.

And what it entails
is that companies

with 100 or more employees must
annually collect and report

on the demographics
of their employees

by job category to the
federal government.

This is mainly a
transaction between the firm
and the federal government.

And the discretion to disclose
this information to the public
is left up to the firm.

So historically, most
companies have not

disclosed this
information to the public.

But as we heard in a
lot of talks today,
things are changing.

Since the Black Lives
Matter protests back

in summer of 2020, consumers
are demanding more action
from companies as well.

And one of these actions
includes the public disclosure
of these EEO-1 reports.

Since 2019, the
share of companies

that actually disclose
this information
has more than doubled.
But I don't know about you.
That seems extremely small--
[LAUGHTER]
--in the grand scheme of things.

And I feel like there's so
much room for improvement here.

And it got us to think
why is it that companies

are so hesitant to
disclose this information.

Are they at a place
that they're not

proud of in terms of
workforce diversity?

So we look at consumers'
brand attitudes

and ultimately their
purchasing decisions

if companies do engage in these
types of disclosures or not.

So I'm going to have time
to talk about one study.

And in this study, it was
preregistered and prolific
academic.

And participants were
randomly assigned
to one of five conditions.
And I'll walk you through them.

The first one is what we call
the unknown nondisclosure
condition.

And this is where
participants read

about a hypothetical
company A similar
to that of Amazon or Walmart.

And we didn't give them
any other information

about the existence of
EEO-1s or any information

on whether company
A disclosed or not.

In the second control
condition, what

we call the known
nondisclosure condition,

we gave them that
additional information

about the existence of EEO-1s
and this federal obligation

that companies have to report
to the federal government.

And we also told them
that company A chose not
to disclose this information.

So not only do companies
have the decision

to disclose or not, they also
have the decision to how much

information do
they want to reveal
if they do choose to disclose.

So we test these different
types of disclosures.

The first one we call the
disaggregate disclosure
condition.

This is where you present
all the diversity statistics

by job category,
potentially highlighting

that racial disparity that's
occurring between the jobs.

So this data is actually
from Amazon's EEO-1 reports.

And they got a lot of
backlash because they actually

presented their data in
aggregate because so then

aggregate disclosure is when
you collapse that information

across the job
categories and you

appear to be more diverse
than you really are.

And finally, we have
a third condition--

what we call joint, where we
presented all the information
in counterbalance.

So here, I'm going to
graph the average brand
attitudes by each condition.

And there are some
key results that I
want to walk you through.

First, between the unknown
nondisclosure condition

and the nondisclosure
condition, so the state

of the world where consumers are
unaware that the EEO-1 report
exists.

When they do find out
about their existence

and they find out that you as
a company are withholding it,

that decreases brand
attitude significantly.

What's interesting, I think,
is the disaggregate disclosure
condition.

So even if you're
being vulnerable

and you're sharing that full
transparency of your workforce

diversity data and
you reveal potentially

a racial disparity
that's occurring,

that's no better nor worse than
the current state of the world

when many people are
unaware that this exists

or they're unaware if you
engage in disclosure or not.

And then all three forms
of disclosure conditions

is better than
consumers finding out

that you're withholding
this information.

So just to wrap, so if you
have a diverse workforce,
you should share it.
It increases brand attitudes.
It obviously doesn't hurt.

And consumers are
looking for it.

And we also argue in
the paper that even

if you are not where you want
to be in terms of workforce

diversity, in the long run
it might be better for you

to disclose because that's
better than consumers

finding out that
you're withholding.
So that's all I have.
Thank you.
